title: Innovation and Trust

OK, so basically as as you as a company you are your mediator in between this social network of people coming and buying and selling.

Your role is basically you have to figure out what can be revealed, right people?
People use this as a platform to sell anything by anything to spam the site.

You want to tell what can be bought or sold and that basically depends on the national boundaries.
For example, you can sell food items in China, but you cannot sell food items in the US.
Nazi memorabilia can be sold in some countries, but cannot be sold in other countries.
What can be bought or sold?
Recently somebody listed a conflict that is shaped like.
The state of Illinois in the United States and the bid went up to about $2000 before eBay pulled it, saying it's a food item.
You cannot sell a conflict on the side, so they had to get creative.
They said it's just a coupon for a conflict.
You buy this coupon and then will ship the conflict along with a coupon here by the conflict for free.
So people get creative and who's trustworthy and whose fraud that's really important.
If you're looking at a transaction, you want to make sure is it a trustworthy transaction, or instead fraudulent transaction.
Now if you think it is a fraudulent but at the same time the person.
Sorry, not a fraudulent user, then you cannot really pull them off the side, so there is there is its nature.
Now you need to manage privacy very clearly because you need to tell just enough about the seller to the buyer and just enough about the buyer to the seller that they can complete the transaction.
But at the same time you cannot reveal a whole lot of information about each other.
I cannot tell when I'm selling an item, who's buying who's actual person buying from me.

I just I just need to know that there is a bid on my item and there's somebody trying to buy and maybe some other identity is like what is the feedback of this person and what have this person bought before so that I know.

I really need it need not tell where this person lives or how many children that person has.

Basically the strong relationship between three things.
So what happens when you come to this account?
Social network case you discover something so discovery can happen various ways you can search for something, or you search on Google and then you're taken to an advertisement.
Or you go to some other site where reading a content and advertisement shows up on the side.
So discovering can happen in very implicit ways.
From discovery there is relevance because you need to be shown the information that's only relevant to you, but at the same time along with elevation, relevance comes.
Issue of trust.
So how much do you trust the information that is shown to you?
How much do you trust the person who you interact with?
An goes back from that output goes back to discovery.

So there is this wishes or I wouldn't call it a vicious, but there's a circuit as cycle between discovery, relevance and trust, which basically makes the network of higher quality and so every time you build a social network you need to look for these three things.
These three entities and see how they interact with each other and you need to basically be able to have measurable representation of these three.
Entities that's kind of the idea here.

Can you freely copy it?

I cannot do that, so that's a violation of the.
It's not a Copyright, but at the same time the originality of my picture.

And how important is structure?
You can look at structure as basically a way of compression, but at the same time.
Then you need to sorted by relevance.
And you need to reveal it at the right time, so that's a market maker maker.
You got some of these issues that you need to deal with.
Alright, so.
One approach would be to say, hey, let's let's use complex algorithm.
The machine to do some of this stuff and a strong lesson learned by us is the machine has no brain.
The machine is really, really stupid.
The machine can do what you ask it to do.
So what we have said is that how much ever stronger algorithm is, how much ever powerful your algorithm is by itself, the machine cannot solve the problems for you.
Can you take all the items in eBay and create a catalog out of it?
Obviously not if we have tried it several times.
If we have failed and several people have said why can't it be done and they have failed also so.
We came up with this idea of augmented intelligence.
Now order submitted intelligence, basically taking the computers and taking human intelligence and combining the two together at the same time.
This is not rocket science, I'm talking.
I mean this is happening already on the web and social network side.
So so the computer does some piece of work the human beings augment that by saying, hey this is right or this is wrong.
Giving the feedback and the feedback gets fed back into the algorithm.
So there is this cycle between what the computer does in what human beings do in the social network and that's basically what we call as human computing.
Our Community computing user community to do the work an if you want the community to do the work for you and then you need to incent the community.
So in our case if you were to say buyers and sellers, how do you incent the sellers to say create described item perfectly right?
How do you?
How do you insert the sellers to create attributes for the items that they create?
Their incentive is that that item is better listed and when better listed items sell better right?
So that is the kind of incentive for them.
So you know the other area of human computing is.
Can you disguise human computing as entertainment so we can do it as incentives?
Or you can do it as entertainment.
I don't know how many of you have heard of the ESP game, so if you're not heard of it, just go to this site called ESP game.org basically.
The author of the site, Levon on he said that he is a statistic that in 2006, about 1.3 billion hours were spent playing Tetris online.
Now if you can harness this time, people spend playing games and use it for some useful purpose.
Actually, some community good can be done out of it, so he created this game where.
He shows an image on the game and you compete with the person on the other side.
Sometimes you compete with the computer.
You don't know if it's a human being or a computer, but at the same time you display.
Play this game of tagging and he came up with the conclusion that he can index, meaning he can tag or label all the images on Google in less than four weeks.
So that's that's the power of human beings when they can work with the computer.
So that's kind of what he is talking about.
At the same time, the same technology is used by, you know, yesterday we had to talk about an Internet archive and last night at the dinner.
People are talking about how can you take all these scripts in hundreds of languages which we have no idea what they are.
Maybe we can turn that into game and that's basically what recapture is.
If I show a font.

If your character in an Indian or Indian games, maybe there is a player who knows that language and he actually he or she actually puts that information and that can be captured and the computer can crunch the numbers.
The same technologies at the same time used for bad things.
For example phishing sites, you know pornography sites show up images and say hey crack this.
And if you crack, this will show you some images of pornographic images.

So people go to these sites that track practice images, those those are used to actually solve captures on other sites, legitimate sites to take over accounts from say, banking sites and stuff like that.
So the same technology is used for good and bad.
So we need to be really careful as to how these technologies.
And applied.
So from there basically one last point I would like to make is that of platform computing.
So platform computing is basically user created software.
So one thing we have in eBay we're looking at is our platforms become so large and so complex that we need to have an abstractable infrastructure.
What is an abstractable infrastructure?
Basically we need to be able to say.
This is what the marketplace looks like now.
You, the community, come in program this marketplace and use it for your own purposes right?
We need to have programmable implementations and we have programmable interfaces so.
It can be a social network that wants to create a marketplace for certain.
Collectible will look very different from a social network that wants to create a marketplace for let's say electronics or something like that.
So they want to have different interfaces but at the same time the underlying infrastructure is the same.
We need to create implementations for that.
We need to be able to take network information from one social network and carry to other networks.
Now Google and Facebook and Myspace are aggressively working on that and we need to do that in a privacy preserving way.
How do you take?
Port networks how do you take information from one network to another network so we have?

We have started doing work in the develop programs in affiliate networks where we're saying you could have a site I was talking to somebody last night and basically said you could have a site where you could be helping small businesses open open their own business online and you could say hey, here's inventory help you manage your inventory and here is an auction site you can set up an you could just sign up as an affiliate rather than actually create a.
Brand new auction site and go use the basin infrastructure.
Now we've seen infrastructure computing like with people from Amazon and Microsoft and all that stuff where they're saying you can host pretty much any application on our infrastructure.
You don't have to worry about the servers you don't have to worry about data, databases and so on, so we are actually living in very interesting times there.

Pretty much any application, any infrastructure, any implementation can be taken from one platform and any data in terms of network data can be taken from one platform and can we put on other platforms so.

As we go into the future when when human beings and computers come together, we're going to see interesting applications and really raising the bar on the kind of applications that we can that we can build.
